dataset.title: Far northeastern Siberia boreal forest data: Thaw depth within experimental burn plots

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biological Sciences, University of Texas-Brownsville, One West University Blvd, LHSB 2.810

abstract.para: This dataset includes thaw depth for two growing seasons (2012 and 2013) within experimental burn plots in far northeastern Cherskii. Data have not been published.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: Global change models predict an increase in fire activity in boreal forests as climate continues to warm and dry. Because fire consumes the soil organic layer (SOL), the layer of undecomposed mosses and roots atop the permafrost, we hypothesized that increased fire severity will increase permafrost thaw by reducing the depth, and therefore insulating capacity, of the SOL. To test this hypothesis, we conducted plot-level (2-m2) experimental burns in July 2012 in a low-density, mature larch stand located near the Northeast Science Station in Cherskii, Siberia. Dried fuels comprised of naturally occurring vegetation were added to plots to achieve four burn treatments based on residual SOL depths: control, low severity (> 8 cm), moderate severity (5-8 cm), and high severity (2-5 cm). Pre-fire and for two growing seasons post-fire (2012 and 2013), we measured thaw depth to determine severity effects on active layer depth and permafrost thaw.

section.title: Sampling Frequency
section.para: Every one to two weeks while at field station; monthly during rest of growing season

dataTable.entityDescription: This dataset includes thaw depth for two growing seasons (2012 and 2013) within experimental burn plots in far northeastern Cherskii. Data have not been published.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Plot number (initially, 1-16. Added another set of controls in summer 2013 (plots 17-20))

textDomain.definition: Plot number (initially, 1-16. Added another set of controls in summer 2013 (plots 17-20))

attribute.attributeDefinition: C= control (shrubs removed), L = low severity, M = moderate severity, H = high severity, TC = control (shrubs intact)

textDomain.definition: C= control (shrubs removed), L = low severity, M = moderate severity, H = high severity, TC = control (shrubs intact)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Location within plot where measurement taken.

textDomain.definition: Location within plot where measurement taken.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Thaw depth not corrected for amount of soil organic layer consumed by fire.
Thaw depth corrected for amount of soil organic layer consumed by fire.
